item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In China, Iron Man’s Muscle Is Fed by Inner Mongolian Milk
item.description: It’s not uncommon for China to ask for editing changes in movies to fit its ideological framework, but in the case of “Iron Man 3,” the movie actually added four minutes of product placements.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: According to an added scene for Chinese audiences, the secret to Iron Man's vitality is a milk drink from Yili dairy.

item.title: India Ink: Is Sexual Abuse of Minors Worse in India? Ink Readers Debate
item.description: Readers react to the death of a 4-year-old rape victim from Madhya Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: Relatives mourning the death of a 4-year-old rape victim in Ghansor, Madhya Pradesh, on Tuesday.

item.title: British TV Personality Pleads Guilty to Sex Abuse of Girls
item.description: Stuart Hall, 83, admitted abuse of girls age 9 to 17, which prosecutors said took place between 1967 and 1986.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: Stuart Hall, 83, pleaded guilty to charges last month.

item.title: Way of the World: Aligning With the Greater Good
item.description: Rewriting the rules of engagement between companies, countries and shareholders might help avoid what some people see as corporate practices that are harmful to the wider community.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Iraq’s Kurds at the Eye of Regional Storm
item.description: From the peace of northern Iraq, Kurdish officials are closely monitoring the violent upheavals afflicting their immediate neighbors. With developments in the wider region closely linked, they cannot afford to ignore the consequences.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Michael Kamber for The New York Times
item.media:description: A thriving market in newly prosperous Erbil.

item.title: Incident on Pakistan Border Stirs Afghan Emotions
item.description: A clash on the border with Pakistan that killed one Afghan border policeman provoked a spontaneous outpouring of nationalist sentiment in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Afghans carried the body of Qasim Khan, a border policeman killed in a clash with Pakistani troops on Thursday in the Gushta district of Jalalabad.

item.title: India Ink: What They Said: Indian National Sarabjit Singh Dies in Pakistan
item.description: Reactions in India to Mr. Singh’s death in Lahore on Thursday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SRUTHI GOTIPATTI
item.media:description: Students paying tributes to Sarabjit Singh at a school in Amritsar, Punjab on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Emeritus Benedict to Take Up Residence at Vatican
item.description: Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, is set return to live in the Vatican on Thursday afternoon, beginning an unprecedented cohabitation: a retired pontiff living alongside a reigning one.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: The Mater Ecclesiae Monastery, where Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, is set return to live in the Vatican.

item.title: India Ink: The Judgment that Acquitted Congress Party Leader Sajjan Kumar
item.description: Three of the five prosecution witnesses did not name Mr. Kumar until more than two decades after the 1984 riots, the 129-page judgment says.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Sikh activists stopped a Metro train in New Delhi on Wednesday during a demonstration against the acquittal of Congress Party leader Sajjan Kumar.

item.title: North Korea’s Sentencing of American Puts U.S. in a Bind
item.description: Efforts by the United States to break North Korea’s habit of blackmailing have been put to a major test with the sentencing of an American to 15 years of hard labor.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Syrian Forces Advance in Homs, Reports Say
item.description: The reported offensive on Thursday came a day after President Bashar al-Assad sought to counter an impression that he was a leader in hiding.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad, center right, paid a visit to an electrical station in Damascus, the capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: Robert Diamond’s Next Life
item.description: Ten months after being pushed out as C.E.O. of Barclays, Diamond tries to be something other than the “unacceptable face of banking.”
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson/Redux, for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diamond, right, without the trappings and entourage of his former life.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: For North Korea, Another Bargaining Chip?
item.description: North Korea has sentenced an American, Kenneth Bae, to 15 years “compulsory labor” for “hostile acts,” according to reports, setting the stage for a ritual: a former American president travels to Pyongyang to ask for his release.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Bobby Lee, via The Register-Guard, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A 1988 file photo shows Kenneth Bae, right, and a friend as freshmen students at the University of Oregon.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 2
item.description: Strikes and anger on International Labor Day; abortion law proposed in Ireland; a new Russian opera house; and a rugby team’s challenge.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Riot police officers walked through tear gas on Wednesday in Istanbul, where people gathered for a rally despite an official ban.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Amsterdam, the Golden Age of Museum Renovation
item.description: Just in time for coronation week, the Van Gogh Museum, the Rijksmuseum and the Stedelijk are all finally open again.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Vincent van Gogh's "Self-portrait," from 1887-1888, is on view at the newly reopened museum that bears his name.

item.title: China Accused of Denying Care to Chen Guangcheng’s Nephew
item.description: The family of Chen Guangcheng, the blind Chinese dissident whose daring escape from house arrest embarrassed China, says his nephew is not getting treatment for appendicitis.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Indian Prisoner in Pakistan Dies After Beating
item.description: The fate of Sarabjit Singh, on death row for espionage, had long been a source of contention between India and Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: North Korea Sentences American to 15 Years of Hard Labor
item.description: Kenneth Bae, who ran a tour business out of China and was arrested in November, was convicted of committing hostile acts against the government.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Lede: In Russian Social Media, Glimpse of Students Accused of Hiding Boston Evidence
item.description: The two Kazakh students arrested on charges of destroying evidence in the Boston Marathon bombing case documented their life in the United States and their relationship with the surviving bombing suspect.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: One of those charged, Dias Kadyrbayev, left, with the surviving suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, in a photo from the social network VK.

item.title: Some Retailers Rethink Their Role in Bangladesh
item.description: The Walt Disney Company has ordered an end to production of branded merchandise in Bangladesh, and other retailers are considering similar moves.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Bangladeshis buried the dead Wednesday in Dhaka. The collapse of a clothing manufacturing center killed more than 400 people.

item.title: Older British Stars Caught Up in Operation Yewtree
item.description: An investigation into offenses that may or may not have been committed decades ago has resulted in a flurry of arrests and has many people asking who will be next.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: The entertainer Rolf Harris has been caught up in Operation Yewtree, a nationwide inquiry into sexual offenses that may or may not have been committed decades ago.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Critic of Morsi Is Jailed
item.description: Egyptian authorities jailed an anti-Islamist activist late Tuesday on charges that included insulting President Mohamed Morsi, state news media said.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Libya: 3 Sought for Questioning in Benghazi Attack
item.description: The F.B.I. on Wednesday released photos of three men wanted in connection with the attacks on an American diplomatic mission and C.I.A. outpost in Benghazi, Libya, in September.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Order Restored After Sectarian Violence
item.description: Hundreds of police officers and troops restored order in central Myanmar on Wednesday after a new outbreak of sectarian violence in which one man was killed.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Rebel Group Suspends Peace Talks
item.description: The rebel group M23 has suspended peace talks with the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo, a rebel spokesman said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
